messageBody:
Curt Sampson wrote:

> On Mon, 25 Aug 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> > One talented programmer does the work of five not-so-talented
> > ones at 60% of the price (of the five).
>
> Actually, one talented programmer often does things that no number of
> non-talented programmers can do. For example, produce a system that is
> ready to roll out into production at any time at all, given at most a
> few hours notice. Or create a system such that a full production release
> of a huge system can be done in a couple of hours.

Agreed.

> Unfortuantely, it can be a lot easier to hire five, or even twenty,
> not-so-talented programmers than one talented one.

So it costs less to spend more? Great. Just when I think I begin to
understand business people....

> > > > In my current project, we don't even have any dedicated QA people...
>
> > Hm. Do you mean that you don't have people who test full time? or you
> > don't have people will formal testing experience and/or raw testing
> skill?
>
> We don't have people who test full time, in the sense of someone devoted
> to writing customer and functional tests. Everybody helps out a bit with
> the customer tests, though some more than others, and the functional
> tests are done by the programmers as they work on somethign that needs
> functional testing.
>
> But another point of view would be that "everyone is a full-time tester"
> in that everyone is expected to make sure the code has reasonable test
> coverage, and not just for the programmers' unit tests.

Let me offer: Everyone is a member of the team, many of which are better
at testing and therefore execute/write tests more often than others.
>
> > Google "What is exploratory testing?"
>
> Interesting. Does this quote really describe exploratory testing?
>
> To the extent that the next test we do is influenced by the result
> of the last test we did, we are doing exploratory testing.
>
> (http://www.satisfice.com/articles/what_is_et.htm)
>
> This seems to me that it could just as well describe test-first
> programming; I often decide what my next test will be based on the
> previous tests I've just produced. ("Hmmm. We just saw and fixed a
> failure like such-and-such, does that mean that this other thing might
> be able to fail like that, too? Let's write a test and find out.")

Yes, that's accurate. When James came to XP/AU 2002 we discussed it in
some detail. I wish I understood ET as well then as I do now, because I
would have got more out of the conversations we had.

> It sounds to me like the "scripted testing" he's talking about in that
> article is not XP-style testing, where you run the tests as you come
> up with them, but instead one where you create a whole series of tests
> before you take them to the code. Especially where he says:
>
> Scripting has its place. I can imagine testing situations where
> efficiency and repeatability are so important that we should script
> or automate them.
>
> I can't imagine a situation where efficiency and repeatability are
> *not* important enough to script the tests! But if you can somehow
> manipulate the system quickly enough to do exploratory testing, you can
> probably come up with a way for the script to manipulate the system even
> more quickly, and then just add your tests to the script, rather than
> throwing them away as soon as you've tried them out.

I view testing in the XP/Agile context from two perspectives.

* Test-Driven Development
* Continuous Regression Testing

TDD is about using tests to drive the design. CRT is about capturing the
knowledge we gain from ET to avoid reintroducing problems. CRT supports
refactoring by providing the safety net. Programmers and Customers alike
can do ET.

James and his associates worry that we focus on automating tests, rather
than learning from them. To that extent, they had something to worry
about. I am learning to remember to learn from tests and I am learning
to view that as perhaps the most important aspect of testing, followed
by verifying features and enabling design improvement.

Take care.
